speaker: AJAX
text_entry: SCENE II. Troy. A room in Priam's palace.

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: Enter PRIAM, HECTOR, TROILUS, PARIS, and HELENUS

speaker: PRIAM
text_entry: After so many hours, lives, speeches spent,

speaker: PRIAM
text_entry: Thus once again says Nestor from the Greeks:

speaker: PRIAM
text_entry: 'Deliver Helen, and all damage else--

speaker: PRIAM
text_entry: As honour, loss of time, travail, expense,

speaker: PRIAM
text_entry: Wounds, friends, and what else dear that is consumed

speaker: PRIAM
text_entry: In hot digestion of this cormorant war--

speaker: PRIAM
text_entry: Shall be struck off.' Hector, what say you to't?

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Though no man lesser fears the Greeks than I

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: As far as toucheth my particular,

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Yet, dread Priam,

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: There is no lady of more softer bowels,

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: More spongy to suck in the sense of fear,

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: More ready to cry out 'Who knows what follows?'

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Than Hector is: the wound of peace is surety,

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Surety secure; but modest doubt is call'd

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: The beacon of the wise, the tent that searches

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: To the bottom of the worst. Let Helen go:

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Since the first sword was drawn about this question,

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Every tithe soul, 'mongst many thousand dismes,

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Hath been as dear as Helen; I mean, of ours:

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: If we have lost so many tenths of ours,

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: To guard a thing not ours nor worth to us,

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Had it our name, the value of one ten,

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: What merit's in that reason which denies

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: The yielding of her up?

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Fie, fie, my brother!

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Weigh you the worth and honour of a king

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: So great as our dread father in a scale

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Of common ounces? will you with counters sum

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: The past proportion of his infinite?

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: And buckle in a waist most fathomless

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: With spans and inches so diminutive

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: As fears and reasons? fie, for godly shame!

speaker: HELENUS
text_entry: No marvel, though you bite so sharp at reasons,

speaker: HELENUS
text_entry: You are so empty of them. Should not our father

speaker: HELENUS
text_entry: Bear the great sway of his affairs with reasons,

speaker: HELENUS
text_entry: Because your speech hath none that tells him so?

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: You are for dreams and slumbers, brother priest;

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: You fur your gloves with reason. Here are

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: your reasons:

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: You know an enemy intends you harm;

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: You know a sword employ'd is perilous,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: And reason flies the object of all harm:

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Who marvels then, when Helenus beholds

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: A Grecian and his sword, if he do set

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: The very wings of reason to his heels

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: And fly like chidden Mercury from Jove,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Or like a star disorb'd? Nay, if we talk of reason,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Let's shut our gates and sleep: manhood and honour

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Should have hare-hearts, would they but fat

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: their thoughts

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: With this cramm'd reason: reason and respect

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Make livers pale and lustihood deject.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Brother, she is not worth what she doth cost

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: The holding.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: What is aught, but as 'tis valued?

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: But value dwells not in particular will;

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: It holds his estimate and dignity

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: As well wherein 'tis precious of itself

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: As in the prizer: 'tis mad idolatry

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: To make the service greater than the god

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: And the will dotes that is attributive

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: To what infectiously itself affects,

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Without some image of the affected merit.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: I take to-day a wife, and my election

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Is led on in the conduct of my will;

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: My will enkindled by mine eyes and ears,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Two traded pilots 'twixt the dangerous shores

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Of will and judgment: how may I avoid,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Although my will distaste what it elected,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: The wife I chose? there can be no evasion

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: To blench from this and to stand firm by honour:

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: We turn not back the silks upon the merchant,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: When we have soil'd them, nor the remainder viands

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: We do not throw in unrespective sieve,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Because we now are full. It was thought meet

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Paris should do some vengeance on the Greeks:

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Your breath of full consent bellied his sails;

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: The seas and winds, old wranglers, took a truce

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: And did him service: he touch'd the ports desired,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: And for an old aunt whom the Greeks held captive,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: He brought a Grecian queen, whose youth and freshness

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Wrinkles Apollo's, and makes stale the morning.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Why keep we her? the Grecians keep our aunt:

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Is she worth keeping? why, she is a pearl,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Whose price hath launch'd above a thousand ships,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: And turn'd crown'd kings to merchants.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: If you'll avouch 'twas wisdom Paris went--

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: As you must needs, for you all cried 'Go, go,'--

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: If you'll confess he brought home noble prize--

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: As you must needs, for you all clapp'd your hands

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: And cried 'Inestimable!'--why do you now

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: The issue of your proper wisdoms rate,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: And do a deed that fortune never did,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Beggar the estimation which you prized

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Richer than sea and land? O, theft most base,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: That we have stol'n what we do fear to keep!

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: But, thieves, unworthy of a thing so stol'n,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: That in their country did them that disgrace,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: We fear to warrant in our native place!

speaker: CASSANDRA
text_entry: [Within]  Cry, Trojans, cry!

speaker: PRIAM
text_entry: What noise? what shriek is this?

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: 'Tis our mad sister, I do know her voice.

speaker: CASSANDRA
text_entry: [Within]  Cry, Trojans!

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: It is Cassandra.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Enter CASSANDRA, raving

speaker: CASSANDRA
text_entry: Cry, Trojans, cry! lend me ten thousand eyes,

speaker: CASSANDRA
text_entry: And I will fill them with prophetic tears.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Peace, sister, peace!

speaker: CASSANDRA
text_entry: Virgins and boys, mid-age and wrinkled eld,

speaker: CASSANDRA
text_entry: Soft infancy, that nothing canst but cry,

speaker: CASSANDRA
text_entry: Add to my clamours! let us pay betimes

speaker: CASSANDRA
text_entry: A moiety of that mass of moan to come.

speaker: CASSANDRA
text_entry: Cry, Trojans, cry! practise your eyes with tears!

speaker: CASSANDRA
text_entry: Troy must not be, nor goodly Ilion stand;

speaker: CASSANDRA
text_entry: Our firebrand brother, Paris, burns us all.

speaker: CASSANDRA
text_entry: Cry, Trojans, cry! a Helen and a woe:

speaker: CASSANDRA
text_entry: Cry, cry! Troy burns, or else let Helen go.

speaker: CASSANDRA
text_entry: Exit

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Now, youthful Troilus, do not these high strains

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Of divination in our sister work

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Some touches of remorse? or is your blood

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: So madly hot that no discourse of reason,

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Nor fear of bad success in a bad cause,

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Can qualify the same?

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Why, brother Hector,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: We may not think the justness of each act

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Such and no other than event doth form it,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Nor once deject the courage of our minds,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Because Cassandra's mad: her brain-sick raptures

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Cannot distaste the goodness of a quarrel

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Which hath our several honours all engaged

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: To make it gracious. For my private part,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: I am no more touch'd than all Priam's sons:

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: And Jove forbid there should be done amongst us

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Such things as might offend the weakest spleen

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: To fight for and maintain!

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Else might the world convince of levity

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: As well my undertakings as your counsels:

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: But I attest the gods, your full consent

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Gave wings to my propension and cut off

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: All fears attending on so dire a project.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: For what, alas, can these my single arms?

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: What Propugnation is in one man's valour,

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: To stand the push and enmity of those

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: This quarrel would excite? Yet, I protest,

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Were I alone to pass the difficulties

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: And had as ample power as I have will,

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Paris should ne'er retract what he hath done,

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Nor faint in the pursuit.

speaker: PRIAM
text_entry: Paris, you speak

speaker: PRIAM
text_entry: Like one besotted on your sweet delights:

speaker: PRIAM
text_entry: You have the honey still, but these the gall;

speaker: PRIAM
text_entry: So to be valiant is no praise at all.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Sir, I propose not merely to myself

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: The pleasures such a beauty brings with it;

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: But I would have the soil of her fair rape

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Wiped off, in honourable keeping her.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: What treason were it to the ransack'd queen,

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Disgrace to your great worths and shame to me,

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Now to deliver her possession up

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: On terms of base compulsion! Can it be

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: That so degenerate a strain as this

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Should once set footing in your generous bosoms?

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: There's not the meanest spirit on our party

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Without a heart to dare or sword to draw

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: When Helen is defended, nor none so noble

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Whose life were ill bestow'd or death unfamed

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Where Helen is the subject; then, I say,

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Well may we fight for her whom, we know well,

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: The world's large spaces cannot parallel.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Paris and Troilus, you have both said well,

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: And on the cause and question now in hand

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Have glozed, but superficially: not much

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Unlike young men, whom Aristotle thought

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Unfit to hear moral philosophy:

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: The reasons you allege do more conduce

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: To the hot passion of distemper'd blood

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Than to make up a free determination

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: 'Twixt right and wrong, for pleasure and revenge

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Have ears more deaf than adders to the voice

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Of any true decision. Nature craves

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: All dues be render'd to their owners: now,

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: What nearer debt in all humanity

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Than wife is to the husband? If this law

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Of nature be corrupted through affection,

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: And that great minds, of partial indulgence

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: To their benumbed wills, resist the same,

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: There is a law in each well-order'd nation

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: To curb those raging appetites that are

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Most disobedient and refractory.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: If Helen then be wife to Sparta's king,

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: As it is known she is, these moral laws

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Of nature and of nations speak aloud

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: To have her back return'd: thus to persist

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: In doing wrong extenuates not wrong,

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: But makes it much more heavy. Hector's opinion

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Is this in way of truth; yet ne'ertheless,

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: My spritely brethren, I propend to you

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: In resolution to keep Helen still,

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: For 'tis a cause that hath no mean dependance

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Upon our joint and several dignities.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Why, there you touch'd the life of our design:

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Were it not glory that we more affected

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Than the performance of our heaving spleens,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: I would not wish a drop of Trojan blood

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Spent more in her defence. But, worthy Hector,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: She is a theme of honour and renown,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: A spur to valiant and magnanimous deeds,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Whose present courage may beat down our foes,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: And fame in time to come canonize us;

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: For, I presume, brave Hector would not lose

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: So rich advantage of a promised glory

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: As smiles upon the forehead of this action

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: For the wide world's revenue.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: I am yours,

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: You valiant offspring of great Priamus.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: I have a roisting challenge sent amongst

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: The dun and factious nobles of the Greeks

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Will strike amazement to their drowsy spirits:

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: I was advertised their great general slept,

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Whilst emulation in the army crept:

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: This, I presume, will wake him.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Exeunt
